member.name: T:Ace.Core.Client.AceClient
member.summary: A client-side proxy for a possibly remote instance of AceServer.

member.name: E:Ace.Core.Client.AceClient.AccessLevelChanged
member.summary: An event raised when the access level changes. This is a client-side event only--the ACE server-side doesn't pay attention to user access levels.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.AceClient.#ctor(Ace.Core.Server.IAceServer)
member.summary: Create a proxy object for the specified ACE instance. This is a singleton, so an attempt to create a second one will fail until the first is disposed.
member.param: The ace server associated with the client.

member.name: T:Ace.Core.Client.Controls.Grouping.GenericComparer
member.summary: Comparer that tries to find the 'strongest' comparer for a type. if the type implements a generic IComparable, that is used. otherwise if it implements a normal IComparable, that is used. If neither are implemented, the ToString versions are compared. INullable structures are also supported. This way, the DefaultComparer can compare any object types and can be used for sorting any source.

member.summary: Gets or sets the size at design time. This property is not intended to be set or modified. It is used so Visual Studio Designer stores the control size at design time. member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.DefaultObjectEditor.RefreshEditor
member.summary: Perform an editor refresh. This redraws the properties in property grids and so on. Unlike RequestEditorRefresh, it only works when called from the GUI thread.

member.summary: Request an editor refresh. This redraws the properties in property grids and so on. Unlike RefreshEditor, it will work if called from outside the GUI thread. It calls RefreshEditor from the GUI thread.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.GuiUtil.IsDesignerHosted(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified control is hosted in a Designer. http://dotnetfacts.blogspot.com/2009/01/identifying-run-time-and-design-mode.html http://www.david-gouveia.com/problems-with-designmode-in-winforms/
member.returns: true if the specified control is hosted in a Designer; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.GuiUtil.RegisterControlForLateInit(System.Windows.Forms.UserControl,System.Windows.Forms.Control,Ace.Core.Util.CustomTypeDescriptorBase)
member.summary:
Registers an inner control for a late initialization. This method must be used when a user control is inheriting from another control, and when some inner controls of the parent control are exposed and serialized by the designer. In this particular case, we do not want the Size and Location properties of the inner controls to be set before the layout logic has completed, as it may lead to some inner control being moved twice. So we will record the values of the properties of the inner control during the initialization phase, and push them to the inner controls when the user control will be loaded. See bug 9045. This has been extended with bug 9153: we will now delay every property that will be set by the Designer.
Three situations must be handled: - Control creation, when it is dropped on the Design surface We must keep the initial values of the inner control - Control deserialization (at loading, when it is deserialized by the Designer -or- at run-time, when it is compiled en executed) We must apply the changes generated by the Designer. The tricky thing is that the Designer will generate some code only for the property that differ from their default value. So we have to set the default values to the initial values of the inner control, to be sure that we will detect any changes made by the user.
member.param: The custom type descriptor of the inner control. It wil be used to filter the properties to consider.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.GuiUtil.GetLateInitControl``1(``0)
member.summary: Gets the late initialization control.
member.returns: The late initialization control.

member.name: T:Ace.Core.Client.IAceClientPlugin
member.summary: An interface implemented by client-side ACE plugins. Classes implementing this interface are automatically discovered at client startup, and the Initialize() method called. After all plugins have been created, the Prepare method is then called so the plugin can perform any initialization that is required after all plugins have been initialized. At shutdown, the Dispose() method is called. There are no guarantees as to which order plugins are initialized or disposed.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.IAceClientPlugin.Initialize(Ace.Core.Client.IAceClient)

member.param: The client associated with the plugin.

member.name: M:Ace.Core.Client.IAceClientPlugin.Prepare
member.summary: Called during client startup after all plugins have been initialized.

member.name: T:Ace.Core.Client.IPlugInOptionsControl
member.summary: Base class for all GUIPlugin Options Display Controls.
member.remarks: If a GUIPlugin needs to add an Options tab to the options form display to allow access to user level properties, you need to do the following: 1) Create a Settings file for your project. Make sure all settings are marked as user level settings so they can be both read/write. 2) Create a UserControl to display the settings and change the base class to derive from this class. 3) Add the attribute ObjectEditorAttribute to the user's GuiPlugin object. That provides the link between the plug-in and the options display control

member.name: T:Ace.Core.Client.Visualization.ShapeVisualizer
member.summary: Represents a renderer for an AceObject
member.remarks: There should be 1 DisplayElement in the object that represents the current position of the object. This correlates to the old API tip position node. This node must have then full path name of the AceObject. Any objects relative to another AceObject should set the element ParentName to the full path name of the parent AceObject.

member.name: T:Ace.Core.Server.DataItems.ExposableDataItemWrapper
member.summary:
Represents a data item wrapper that can be set in the propertyGrid control.
It contains a reference to the exposable data item and the corresponding exposable data source.
When an object is added to the propertyGrid, we have to update the propertyGrid when the values of the object change. This require to change the object displayed by the propertyGrid.
